title: The Lore Powercreep Does not Matter
body:
Yes, Riot has producing powerful characters since the removal of the Institute of War. No, this does not mean a damn thing for the lore. 

Powercreep is a factor in game design because every champion should be able to contend with every other champion.  Talon may have to lane against Aurelion Sol, but he can still assassinate the space dragon easily. 

In the lore however, there is almost no reason for Talon and Aurelion to ever have to interact.  Riot’s narrative philosophy is creating a larger world filled with smaller stories.  Ornn and Volibear will continue to clash like the demigods they are, and Ekko will continue to beat up thugs in Zaun. 

This is why I don’t think Powercreep in the lore is a big deal at all.

It's an interesting topic, whichever way you slice it...

I always remind myself: magic users are probably a very small percentage of the overall population of Runeterra, and *champions* in LoL are only the ~140 most exceptional beings in the entire setting (although that number is rising!)

League of Legends, the game, is a team-based abstraction of the lore. When I play X-Wing, I don't think I am playing a canonical Star Wars ship battle - just a competitive game fantasy based on it. :-) And the moment we start looking at lore in a _"My dad could beat up your dad!"_ way, the authenticity rapidly diminishes.

It's not even entirely clear whether all the LoL champions exist at the same time in the lore, although we're trying to clarify that more and more as we go on. For a real world analogy, Julius Caesar couldn't get into a team fight with Ronda Rousey, f'rinstance.

None of this should affect how each player chooses to enjoy the lore or the game, though!

It's hard to get a layout of Runeterra. Humans are the dominant species, and magic users are rare, but we know there are magic soldiers, Twisted Fate's people, etc. What about Ionians? They seem to be the most magical, but how well known are they to the rest of the world?

> It's not even entirely clear whether all the LoL champions exist at the same time in the lore

I don't understand this.

We're working to clarify all of this. :-) It's certainly never been done in a single, directed way before now.

RE: existing at the same time - Qui-Gon Jinn and Luke Skywalker did not exist in the Star Wars universe at the same time, but you can still play them together in games. Does that make sense?
Yes, but in that context, Qui-Gon is dead by the time Luke exists. What exactly does that mean in LoL? Dead characters? People younger than they are in the lore?

Well, it's unclear whether or not some characters _exist_ at all.  For instance, {{champion:201}} and {{champion:240}} are folk heroes of their respective nations, but not all folk heroes are/were actually real people.  Also, {{champion:201}} 's [story](https://universe.leagueoflegends.com/en_US/story/braum-color-story/) is a bedtime story told by someone's grandmother, who heard the story from _her_ grandmother.  So either {{champion:201}} has been dead for a few generations, or he's immortal (or at least ageless, or at the very least not a normal flesh-and-blood human), or he never existed at all.

This is how I see it:

Take for example the Lord of the Rings MOBA. I don't know much about LotR, but I assuming in canon Tolkien lore, many of the characters never faced of and many of the game assets and mechanics never existed. In other words, the LotR MOBA is a representation of the canon lore that Tolkien created put into a game format.

Another thing to realize, in games like LoL or Overwatch, the character in game is just a snapshot/representation of the character in a moment in time. So say if in the lore a champion goes through a major character arc, it wouldn't necessarily be represented in the gameplay.

I'm a slight bit concerned about champions not existing at the same time.  Simply that if they didn't, then, it gets a lot less fun trying to piece it all together.  One of the biggest issues I had with the old IoW lore was that they'd often bring champions across space like Malphite, Taric and Kayle/Morgana.  Isn't this the same issue but with time separating them?  If these events happen centuries apart, then...I suppose I don't feel as invested that this isn't some kind of era-defining time in Runeterra, an age of champions so to speak.  I suppose there would be ways to make it work, but I still feel kind of jilted that for some champions, they'd never even have the opportunity to meet.  It kind of allows for fans to fantasize within reason of what two characters with similar power levels would do when they meet, or how they'd interact.  I'm just a bit disappointed, because I had ideas for a massive interconnecting story, that I was writing for league... But I kinda feel like it might be useless to continue any further knowing that there's no chance something like that actually happening.  I... suppose this is really just me being biased because it was a big dream of mine to finish this story...but my favorite thing about the lore was the fact that it was all interconnected and one champions lore could affect another instead of isolated stories.

I'm going to reply here, but I think this covers several parts of the discussion elsewhere in the thread too... :-)

To be clear: I'm ABSOLUTELY NOT saying that "champions do not exist all at the same time". I'm saying that certain stories do not make it clear whether or not specific champions are active in the same place, at the same time.

This works both ways. If we assume there is a "now" (which there is!) and that all ~140 champs are active right now, then they can all potentially interact with one another in whatever ways make for the best and most exciting stories. You can expect to see more and more of that kind of storytelling in the near future.

However... if there is a "now", then there was a "past", and therefore an implied canonical timeline. Riot has told stories set in the past of the timeline - even the Darius comic showed some events from 5 (?) years ago, and as Xenohaz pointed out, Braum has apparently been around for multiple generations. This means either that humans in our setting don't age or die (seems unlikely!) or that we have to assume that some champions are very unlikely to ever interact outside of the game, because the days, weeks, months and years of their lives are gradually being filled up with storylines.

If we tell a story set 5 years in the past, or an origins story for a champion even further back, then we have to consider the fact that younger champions would be children... or not even born yet. Then you have to literally start working out "when is now?" and how old LITERALLY every single champion is, and whether or not they age like regular people.

That's all I meant :-)

There is positive movement at Riot towards making internally consistent lore - we're not there yet, but we're making progress. I'd urge everyone not to see this as a limiting factor, but a chance to see more stories which have meaningful connections and an internal logic across all of them.

And as always, I welcome your thoughts and feedback on this. I wouldn't be here if I didn't want to hear what you all had to say.

That **CAN**, and definitely would affect a person's ability to enjoy the lore. The biggest problem with your thought process is that we know the timeline in the Starwars universe. In league we don't. We know when Qui-Gon was around and we know the decisions he made that caused greater effect in the universe. 

League needs a "core" event time. Not one event but simply a span of 50~ years that the cast were all active; a period where 99% of the cast are all present in the universe. Some can continue on from here some will have been champions long before. The exceptions to this should only be champions that had a huge impact in the creation of another champion, but died before "core" event time.

In this essence Luke meets Qui-Gon in a game that's fine. However Julius Ceaser and Ronda Rousey aren't relevant to the same story, and at that scope they aren't really special anymore.

You make a great point. And, FWIW, I agree - Runeterra needs a "now", which will naturally give us a "past" and an implied future.

I think we might actually be on exactly the same page, so I hope I've allayed your concern a little?
It would make the lore feel much much worse if the characters don't all exist at the same time.

Do we have any estimate of how many people are magic users on Runeterra?  Obviously they're a minority, but I'm curious how significant a number they are.  For instance, how likely is it that a random person's met a magic user in their life?

I don't know if a number has ever been put out there. I suggested, anecdotally, it might be <10% of the mortal population (be that humans, or whatever else) and no one in that particular Rioter discussion disagreed. But that's far from canon! :-)

You then have species like the vastaya, who are very connected to magic. Or demons, which are purely spiritual forms. Or ageless space dragons, who... well, you get the idea! Those races skew the average in certain ways, in certain places, at certain times. Ionia is far more magical than Noxus, and Demacia is profoundly anti-magic (in theory).

I'd say... think of it in terms of "how likely is it that a random person in the real world has met someone who owns an iPhone?" Because although there are countless diehard Apple fans across the world, the brand doesn't have as much market presence in some countries/cultures, or some people just prefer Android, some people don't have a phone at all, etc.
In your lifetime? Sure, you probably met at least one iPhone owner. But that could just be where you live, or how wealthy you are, etc. It's all relative.

So yes, confirmed. Smartphones = real world magic. ;-)

Would you want it to be something like the percentage of humans who practice Wicca in the USA since I remember someone talking about how there's less then 1 million people who consider themselves wiccan in the USA. And due to the ideas people have about Wicca a person will probably meet a wiccan but will not know they have, would that be kind of what's going on with magic in Runeterra or would that be more specifcally how it is in Demacia where you might pass by someone who actually has magic but you and them won't know because of the anti-magic views of Demacia and the amount of Petricite.
I'd have to learn more about the sort of numbers and context you're talking about, but that certainly seems like a similar idea, at least :-)

I don't know how Riot stating 'these champs don't even exist at the same time as each other' shouldn't affect someone's way of enjoying the lore, though. That's like saying 'it is physically impossible for Talon to kill Sol. Feel free to write stories about him doing so, though'. And are you saying no one can be a fan if they can't contribute to the canon themselves? I mean, I've never contributed to Battlestar Galactica, but I would still call myself a fan.

I think me saying 'stories' muddled my point. My bad.

The point I was getting at is that actively saying  'these champs might not exist at the same time' or 'the authenticity diminishes if you try to figure out power levels' absolutely has an affect on how people enjoy the lore, and I don't see how you can pretend otherwise.

Does fan fiction inspire canon? For example, do you read a convincing prospect about Kindred meeting Urf? Is Urf even canon? Have you ever read something in, say, one of the writing competitions, and thought that it would fit into LoL really well? I guess I'm just curious about the influence the community has in terms of the canon lore.

League had a rule at least a few years ago where the lore team wasn't able to look at League fanfiction to make sure they didn't accidentally copy anything from it and in turn get in trouble for properly giving credit, I remember since I had suggested a few people read Spellthief which is a really long and good fanfiction about a mission Lux takes undercover in Noxus.

This is correct, we cannot read fan-fiction.

However, we can and do keep up to date with player theories, and what they'd like to see - Riot literally has teams dedicated to asking players what they like and don't like. And sometimes, those wishes can inspire teams to take an idea in a new direction.

In the words of a wise man... "What the actual fuh-?"

Eight years of retcons, controversial rewrites, the creation of a department in charge of world building, and all the other drama from Narrative... and no one's thought to answer the fundamental question of whether or not these champs exist in the same time frame?

I mean, this is one of those questions that should be clarified and confirmed from the outset, so we fans know who we should invest our time and energy in.

I mean, if Braum was just a fairy tale told to Freljord children to help them feel safe during the harsh winters and not a living champ that wants to introduce Alistar to his cow, this should be established as soon as possible.

Otherwise, you'll get more resentment when fans and players realize that all the time and energy they spent enjoying their favorite champ was just wasted once the truth is revealed.

> None of this should affect how each player chooses to enjoy the lore or the game, though!

It does, however, and to suggest otherwise is surprising naive.

Given how attached some players get to their favorite champs, finding out that all their time, love and energy was wasted on a long-dead character that will never interact with the current story would be devastating to them.

At least with Sol, we can read about him providing commentary about Runeterra.
